﻿                                 SCHEDULE 2                                                           <br /><br /><br />
               DESCRIPTION OF PRE-FEASIBILITY STUDY ACTIVITIES                                        <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                      <br /><br /><br />
This section comprises a summary of the exploration / PFS work programme envisaged by                 <br /><br /><br />
the Company. It is intended to illustrate works planned and should not be interpreted as              <br /><br /><br />
exhaustive or comprehensive.                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
1.1 Description of Exploration Activities Planned:                                                    <br /><br /><br />
The exploration work programme described in this section 1 comprises one key component                <br /><br /><br />
of a Pre-Feasibility Study on the Western Cluster iron ore project, leading to the generation         <br /><br /><br />
of a CRIRSCO-compliant Indicated Resource estimate.                                                   <br /><br /><br />
The PFS report for the Bomi and Mano River Deposits will be completed in the 1st phase and            <br /><br /><br />
a copy will be provided to the government no later than the second anniversary of the                 <br /><br /><br />
Effective Date, while the PFS for the Bea Mountain Deposits will be completed and a copy              <br /><br /><br />
provided to the Government no later than the third anniversary of the effective date. PFS             <br /><br /><br />
studies typically allow the project owner to evaluate and select the most economically and            <br /><br /><br />
technically viable option for project development, with 5-15% of engineering completed,               <br /><br /><br />
project specific cost estimates with an accuracy of ±20% and 15-20% Contingency. A                    <br /><br /><br />
detailed description of the scope of work for the generation of the resource estimate and for         <br /><br /><br />
the remainder of the PFS is presented at section 2.                                                   <br /><br /><br />
The primary objective of the exploration work programme presented in this section, is to              <br /><br /><br />
generate CRIRSCO-standard Indicated Resource estimates at Bomi, Mano River and Bea                    <br /><br /><br />
Mountain Deposits.                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
12 Drilling:                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
Detailed work program will be developed and estimation of the drilling required to establish          <br /><br /><br />
Indicated Resources according to the definitions in the CRIRSCO reporting Template will be            <br /><br /><br />
made. The number of holes and proposed drilled meterage by area will be recorded. Holes               <br /><br /><br />
will be drilled via a combination of diamond drilling (DD) and reverse circulation (RC)               <br /><br /><br />
drilling.                                                                                             <br /><br /><br />
1.3    Airborne Magnetic Survey:                                                                      <br /><br /><br />
Company plans to engage magnetic survey over the deposit area to identify potential iron              <br /><br /><br />
bearing zone for planning of detailed exploration drilling program. The objectives of this            <br /><br /><br />
survey are i) to provide high resolution geomagnetic imagery to Locate the outcrop of                 <br /><br /><br />
Mineralization in the deposit area more accurately it) to provide rigorous geomagnetic data           <br /><br /><br />
for regional geological interpretation iii) to generate a digital elevation model, corrected for      <br /><br /><br />
forest cover and iv) to generate aerial photographic imagery for use in environmental and             <br /><br /><br />
social baseline studies.                                                                              <br /><br /><br />
1.4    Ground Magnetic Survey:                                                                        <br /><br /><br />
Company plans to conduct limited ground magnetic survey at Deposit Locations with the                 <br /><br /><br />
objective of providing information to assist with the location of drill-hole collars prior to the     <br /><br /><br />
receipt of airborne magnetic data, as well as providing information to assist interpretation of       <br /><br /><br />
the depth extent of the mineralisation at Deposits.                                                   <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                      <br /><br /><br />
                                v                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
﻿1.5    Metallurgical Testing:                                                                  <br /><br /><br />
Company plans to conduct orientation mineralogical analysis of samples from drill cores.       <br /><br /><br />
This analysis will include i) quantitative X-ray analysis of mineral content (XRD), ii)        <br /><br /><br />
petrographic analysis, iii) mineralographic analysis, iv) optic-gcometrical analysis, v)       <br /><br /><br />
spectroscopic analysis, and vi) Mdssbauer Spectroscopy. The results of this orientation        <br /><br /><br />
mineralogical study will provide guidance for the detailed design of the follow-up optical     <br /><br /><br />
mineralogy studies planned during subsequent metallurgical testing. Bench-scale                <br /><br /><br />
metallurgical testing will be completed on large (c. 400 kg) samples.                          <br /><br /><br />
1.6    Analytical Works:                                                                       <br /><br /><br />
The sample preparation and analytical methodology will be based on input from international    <br /><br /><br />
consultants. Davis Tube Recovery' (DTR) methodology will be used to ensure the                 <br /><br /><br />
methodology facilitates extraction of maximum- information from Deposit samples. The           <br /><br /><br />
sample preparation and analytical methodology will comprise of i) sample preparation, with     <br /><br /><br />
different approaches used for different ore type samples, ii) major element geochemical        <br /><br /><br />
analysis, iii) DTR testing of samples, and iv) deleterious trace element determination on DTR  <br /><br /><br />
concentrate composites.                                                                        <br /><br /><br />
1.7    Exploration Infrastructure:                                                             <br /><br /><br />
Proper Exploration infrastructure will be created to operate an exploration camp comprising    <br /><br /><br />
i) diesel fuel storage facility, ii) light vehicle workshop, iii) wells and pumps, iv) site    <br /><br /><br />
security infrastructure, v) senior staff accommodation, vi) junior staff accommodation, vii)   <br /><br /><br />
office block-building, viii) kitchen / mess block building, ix) VSAT communications            <br /><br /><br />
equipment, x) core shed for core cutting, sample preparation and core storage, xi)             <br /><br /><br />
containerised water treatment plant, xii) containerised sewage treatment plant, xiii)          <br /><br /><br />
incinerator, and xiv) over 600 kVA of diesel generating capacity. Company will provide         <br /><br /><br />
laundry, room cleaning and 3 meals i day for camp residents, as well as a casual meals         <br /><br /><br />
service for temporary labourers recruited from the surrounding villages, and also provide      <br /><br /><br />
office cleaning services and operate a camp shop and cash bar.                                 <br /><br /><br />
2. Scope of Work for PFS, Including Evaluation of processing, transportation and               <br /><br /><br />
export of iron ore from free port of Monrovia                                                  <br /><br /><br />
Company intends to evaluate the Western Cluster iron ore project in two stages:                <br /><br /><br />
i)    A Prefeasibility Study (PFS) which shall satisfy the requirements of this Agreement, and <br /><br /><br />
during which all alternative project concepts are assessed in sufficient thoroughness that     <br /><br /><br />
company can commit to a single project option that provides a viable, low risk business case,  <br /><br /><br />
for which further information would need to be gathered and assessed during a DFS.             <br /><br /><br />
ii)    A Definitive Feasibility Study (DFS) which shall satisfy the requirements of this       <br /><br /><br />
Agreement, and during which the project is assessed in sufficient thoroughness that company    <br /><br /><br />
could subsequently commit to the project, subject to it meeting company’s investment and       <br /><br /><br />
other criteria. This DFS should be completed to the standard expected by international         <br /><br /><br />
financial institutions and their technical advisers.                                           <br /><br /><br />
In this section is described a typical PFS scope of work for an iron ore project in Liberia,   <br /><br /><br />
which is likely to be applied to the Western Cluster iron ore project. This description is not <br /><br /><br />
﻿presented as being cither exhaustive in scope or complete in its detail. It should also be read      <br /><br /><br />
in conjunction with section 1 above, which outlines the exploration works planned by                 <br /><br /><br />
company to generate data for a CRIRSCO-compliant indicated mineral resource estimate,                <br /><br /><br />
which is a key component of the PFS.                                                                 <br /><br /><br />
2.1    Scope of Pre Feasibility Study                                                                <br /><br /><br />
The manner of execution of the pre feasibility and feasibility stages of a project and their         <br /><br /><br />
scope extent can have a profound impact on the successful outcome of the project,                    <br /><br /><br />
Adequate investment in these phases is necessary to ensure success. A PFS typically                  <br /><br /><br />
addresses the following factors relating to the development of a mining Project i.e. i) strategy     <br /><br /><br />
and market analysis, ii) assessment of the likely technical and Economic viability of a set of       <br /><br /><br />
alternative mining, process, location, capacity and project configuration alternatives to            <br /><br /><br />
determine the preferred alternative for a DFS, iii) determination of the material risks, key         <br /><br /><br />
value drivers and risk/reward profile, iv) a description of the alternatives and final               <br /><br /><br />
recommendation, and v) development of a work plan, schedule, cost, resources and services            <br /><br /><br />
requirements necessary to undertake project development through the feasibility study to             <br /><br /><br />
implementation. The PFS report will typically contain the chapters described in the following        <br /><br /><br />
sections plus an executive summary that clearly summarises the content of the study report in        <br /><br /><br />
a concise manner and presents the project strategy and recommended project configuration to          <br /><br /><br />
be studied further in the DFS stage.                                                                 <br /><br /><br />
2.2    Market Analysis                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
The objective of this work is to support Company’s PFS with an overview of the current and           <br /><br /><br />
projected global iron ore industry - its products, suppliers, customers and cost drivers and         <br /><br /><br />
the positioning of Western Cluster iron ore products in that competitive .environment. This          <br /><br /><br />
overview will include i) industry competitors, ii) market overview and iii) industry cost            <br /><br /><br />
drivers. The data presented will be drawn together and some concluding remarks offered               <br /><br /><br />
which detail both the historical and future attractiveness of the iron ore industry with             <br /><br /><br />
particular focus on the dynamics of the Atlantic Basin. A marketing and pricing strategy for         <br /><br /><br />
the Western Cluster iron ore products will be presented.                                             <br /><br /><br />
2.3    Geology and Mineral Resources                                                                 <br /><br /><br />
Company will continue to load and maintain a comprehensive electronic database that                  <br /><br /><br />
contains records of numerous attributes of geological samples, as well as results of tests to        <br /><br /><br />
establish the quality (accuracy and precision) of the geological data, and metadata recording        <br /><br /><br />
test methods, batch numbers, limits of detection, etc. The contents of the geological database       <br /><br /><br />
will be reviewed against original survey records, geological logs, and laboratory reports to         <br /><br /><br />
establish the reliability of the information within the database. The geological data will then      <br /><br /><br />
be interpreted and the sequence subdivided into rock units that are meaningful to mining and/        <br /><br /><br />
or mineral processing, and are as mineralogically and grade homogenous as possible. The              <br /><br /><br />
spatial distribution of these rock units will be interpreted, and samples assigned to these units.   <br /><br /><br />
The data from samples within each unit would then be assessed to establish the characteristics       <br /><br /><br />
of the unit, and the distance over which grades are statistically related within each unit (i.e.     <br /><br /><br />
geostatistics).                                                                                      <br /><br /><br />
A digital cellular resource model will be created that contains estimates of rock type, grades       <br /><br /><br />
of mineralisation, and density of all rocks, for all rock units in the proposed volume to be         <br /><br /><br />
mined. This resource model will be the basis for estimates of Mineral Resources, and mine            <br /><br /><br />
design leading to estimates of Mineral Reserves. The estimates of Mineral Resources will be          <br /><br /><br />
classified according to definitions in the CRIRSCO reporting template.                               <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
 ''N                                                                                                 <br /><br /><br />
﻿ 2.4 Mining                                                                                         <br /><br /><br />
 The PFS will investigate and report on a number of alternative scenarios to generate               <br /><br /><br />
 preliminary mine development plans to exploit the Western Cluster iron ore resource. The           <br /><br /><br />
 aim is to narrow down the process and productivity alternatives into a single business case.       <br /><br /><br />
 The level of detail required in the study must be sufficient to ensure the alternatives are        <br /><br /><br />
 correctly ranked and the one selected scenario will deliver the best possible outcome.             <br /><br /><br />
 The mine planning activities undertaken as part of the PFS will include provision of i) an         <br /><br /><br />
 overall description of the site layout, ii) a summary description of the key issues in describing  <br /><br /><br />
 the geological resource, including a description of tire geological block model, material          <br /><br /><br />
 characteristics and resource estimate, iii) the key geotechnical parameters and hydro              <br /><br /><br />
 geological considerations including wall stability, surface and groundwater conditions etc. iv)    <br /><br /><br />
 an understanding of the main environmental and cultural considerations, and v) a summary           <br /><br /><br />
 description of the assumptions used to generate a mine design to a high level of confidence        <br /><br /><br />
 (basis of design document), including the main economic criteria to be applied to the project,     <br /><br /><br />
 process recovery and marketing. The mining methods being considered will be then be                <br /><br /><br />
 discussed and defined, The first task in the execution stage of the PFS will be to generate a      <br /><br /><br />
 mineable resource model, taking into account such factors as cut-off grade, ore dilution and       <br /><br /><br />
 ore recovery. This model will be used as the basis for the pit optimisation strategic study. The   <br /><br /><br />
 assessment of the model and project requirements will assist in the definition of the mine         <br /><br /><br />
 production rate for each of the alternative options. The preliminary definition of ore and         <br /><br /><br />
 waste will follow. Based on reference to physical and economic parameters, a high level pit        <br /><br /><br />
 optimisation assessment will be undertaken. Once the optimum pit shells (including cut-back        <br /><br /><br />
 sequence) have been selected, a strategic approach to pit development will follow. An              <br /><br /><br />
 indicative pit design with mineral inventory statement will be created, Scheduling of the mine     <br /><br /><br />
 will provide a practical mine production sequence for the development of the deposit. The          <br /><br /><br />
 PFS will also investigate the waste and overburden removal strategy and stockpile and dump         <br /><br /><br />
 designs. The task then is to investigate the material handling alternatives to establish truck     <br /><br /><br />
 fleet or other material handling configurations. The operating and capital costs will then be      <br /><br /><br />
 estimated and will include high level manning and infrastructure requirements. A summary           <br /><br /><br />
 list of the mine equipment requirements will be made for each alternative, to suit the             <br /><br /><br />
 production constraints and mining method.                                                          <br /><br /><br />
 The alternative scenarios will then be tabulated and assessed with trade-off studies to arrive at  <br /><br /><br />
 a single “go forward” recommendation from the study. Technical risks associated with the           <br /><br /><br />
 mining aspects of the operation will then be discussed, A future work Program will then be         <br /><br /><br />
 defined to further evaluate the recommended alternative.                                           <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
2.5 Mineral Processing                                                                              <br /><br /><br />
The PFS will investigate and report on the various alternatives considered and the decision         <br /><br /><br />
making process applied to determine the single, “go forward”, DFS case. The level of detail         <br /><br /><br />
and depth of study required must be sufficient to ensure that the selected DFS case will lead       <br /><br /><br />
to the most valuable outcome for Company giving full consideration of the risk vs. reward           <br /><br /><br />
context.                                                                                            <br /><br /><br />
A number of flow sheet options will be developed for the PFS. The study will examine all of         <br /><br /><br />
these options and any others that might arise in sufficient detail to enable a decision to be       <br /><br /><br />
made as to which should become the base case for the DFS. In doing so the following factors,        <br /><br /><br />
amongst others, will be considered; ore characteristics, test work results, environmental           <br /><br /><br />
impacts, capital and operating costs.                                                               <br /><br /><br />
 In the initial stage of the PFS the process design team will liaise with geologists and mining     <br /><br /><br />
 engineers to develop a preliminary product grade model to be used in pit optimisation              <br /><br /><br />
 exercises. Using the preliminary basis for design document prepared from the metallurgical         <br /><br /><br />
﻿test work programme as a starling point, the process design will be developed to provide for      <br /><br /><br />
each option, preliminary; design criteria, flow diagrams, mass balance, equipment sc! ns,         <br /><br /><br />
description and costs. The prediction and control of final product quality is a key element of    <br /><br /><br />
the design which involves close cooperation between mining and process engine'; -. The            <br /><br /><br />
planning of mine schedules, crushing campaigns, mine stockpiles and port stockpiles will be       <br /><br /><br />
conducted as an iterative exercise. The PFS report will contain a description of the              <br /><br /><br />
development of the final recommended flow sheet clearly demonstrating how the flo\. sheet         <br /><br /><br />
was derived from metallurgical test work data, experience at other mines and financial            <br /><br /><br />
evaluation.                                                                                       <br /><br /><br />
A review of available information will be undertaken by the PFS engineering conlnctor to          <br /><br /><br />
identify key site information including i) geological setting, ii) climatic setting, iii)         <br /><br /><br />
Hydrological setting, iv) topographic data, and v) local and regional infrastructure. The         <br /><br /><br />
results of the review will be referenced in conjunction with project requiremt. as ,md            <br /><br /><br />
constraints identified by company and the PFS engineering contractor to identify a preferred      <br /><br /><br />
Plant location and site layout.                                                                   <br /><br /><br />
A preliminary geotechnical investigation will be carried out to assist in the selec ion of        <br /><br /><br />
suitable locations for plant and infrastructure facilities and to provide preliminary data for    <br /><br /><br />
foundation and structural design,                                                                 <br /><br /><br />
Based on the process mass balances equipment selections and sizing will be determined for         <br /><br /><br />
each option and a mechanical layout prepared. Preliminary 3D models will be dev-.; -ped           <br /><br /><br />
including mechanical equipment layout and arrangement, structural elements and piping.            <br /><br /><br />
Material quantities derived from these models and from preliminary engineering designs will       <br /><br /><br />
be used in capital cost estimating. Preliminary power generation, distribution and control        <br /><br /><br />
designs will be prepared. The plant operating, manning and control philosophies will be           <br /><br /><br />
agreed which provide input to the capital and operating cost estimates.                           <br /><br /><br />
2.6 Railroad Infrastructure:                                                                      <br /><br /><br />
Rail road infrastructure, specifically road and rail access to the project site is a key          <br /><br /><br />
component of the project and will require assessment during the PFS. Work will include            <br /><br /><br />
surveying and mapping, geological and geotechnical, and bathymetry and coastal engineering.       <br /><br /><br />
Preliminary environmental and social impact statements.                                           <br /><br /><br />
All options for the ore transport from plant to port will be explored. The PFS engineering and    <br /><br /><br />
cost estimates will be developed to the extent that a single preferred option can be identified.  <br /><br /><br />
The PFS scope of work for the railway will include i) a desktop review of existing                <br /><br /><br />
documentation and identification of route selection constraints including any cadastral,          <br /><br /><br />
geotechnical, hydrological, community and environmental issues, ii) the assessment and            <br /><br /><br />
selection of preferred routes, including survey and measurement where necessary, iii)             <br /><br /><br />
conceptual civil design for the preferred routes, typical formation designs, hydrological         <br /><br /><br />
assessment of major creek crossings and preparation of drawings with typical bridge and           <br /><br /><br />
culvert details where required, iv) identification of track ballast source(s), v) calculations of <br /><br /><br />
optimum train sets required including assessment of commercial viability of both bulk cargo       <br /><br /><br />
and passenger / non-bulk cargo services, vi) preliminary design of mine and port marshalling      <br /><br /><br />
yards and loading/unloading facilities and signalling, communications and control systems,        <br /><br /><br />
and vii) preliminary assessment of operations and maintenance requirements.                       <br /><br /><br />
The PFS scope of work for the port facility will include i) a review' of existing hydrological,   <br /><br /><br />
geological data and facilities available at the Monrovia Port iii) a review of the inlet channel  <br /><br /><br />
and a preliminary estimate of dredging requirements, iv) an optimised vessel size using the       <br /><br /><br />
port, and v) a preliminary design of the quays and jetty. Also the land area required for         <br /><br /><br />
handling, storage and ship loading facilities as required to support planned volumes of export.   <br /><br /><br />
﻿The PFS scope of work for site infrastructure engineering will include evaluation of i)water        <br /><br /><br />
supply, storage and reticulation, ii) sewage collection and treatment, iii) a site layout plan, iv) <br /><br /><br />
site earthworks and drainage, vi) tailings storage facility, vii) accommodation, viii)              <br /><br /><br />
industrial buildings, ix) power supply.                                                             <br /><br /><br />
2.7    Human Resources                                                                              <br /><br /><br />
The PFS will include an examination, at a high level, of the Human Resources (HR) issues            <br /><br /><br />
associated with the operational philosophy and management strategies identified for the             <br /><br /><br />
project. Issues to be addressed include organisational philosophy and model, cultural fit,          <br /><br /><br />
skills requirements, employee relations, recruitment and training and the statutory                 <br /><br /><br />
environment. Cost estimates for initial recruitment and training and ongoing HR related             <br /><br /><br />
activities will be prepared and included in the financial evaluations.                              <br /><br /><br />
2.8    Project Execution                                                                            <br /><br /><br />
The PFS will develop and describe a recommended project execution approach; it should               <br /><br /><br />
describe the alternatives considered and clearly explain why the recommended approach has           <br /><br /><br />
been selected. The preliminary project execution plan will address project scope, design            <br /><br /><br />
criteria, product specifications, quality controls and key safety, health, environmental and        <br /><br /><br />
security issues. A facility and package work breakdown structure will be developed as a basis       <br /><br /><br />
for engineering, estimating and cost control. A recommendation will be made on the                  <br /><br /><br />
approach to engineering and the standards to be applied. Execution methodologies and                <br /><br /><br />
contracting strategies will be examined and a preferred selection made which will form the          <br /><br /><br />
basis of the PFS and subsequent DFS. This will include procurement and contracting                  <br /><br /><br />
strategies for execution, equipment and consumables. A high level project development               <br /><br /><br />
schedule showing major DFS, engineering, construction, commissioning, start-up and ramp             <br /><br /><br />
up activities will be developed.                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
2.9    Operations Management                                                                        <br /><br /><br />
The PFS will address the establishment, commissioning, start up and operating needs of the          <br /><br /><br />
project in terms of the operating philosophy, owner or contractor, organisation and                 <br /><br /><br />
consequent labour, industrial relations and logistical requirements. Specific issues to be          <br /><br /><br />
addressed include organisational structure, resources required and source/conditions of             <br /><br /><br />
employment, accommodation, transport logistics and administration.                                  <br /><br /><br />
2.10    Information Management                                                                      <br /><br /><br />
During the PFS stage the information management and technology requirements of the                  <br /><br /><br />
project during both the execution and operating phases will need to be addressed.                   <br /><br /><br />
Preliminary plans and systems will be developed for the capture, sharing and transfer, back¬        <br /><br /><br />
up and security of data, information and knowledge.                                                 <br /><br /><br />
2.11    Health, Safety', Environment and Community                                                  <br /><br /><br />
For a PFS the role of the environmental and social impact team members is to better define i)       <br /><br /><br />
the environmental legislation and international guidelines the project will need to comply          <br /><br /><br />
with, ii) the environmental and social footprint for the project, iii) the key environmental and    <br /><br /><br />
social risks, and iv) finally to communicate the findings and recommendations for                   <br /><br /><br />
management measures to the project engineering design team. This will allow environmental           <br /><br /><br />
and social issues to be identified early and incorporated into environmental and social design      <br /><br /><br />
criteria and environmental and social management plans for the project.                             <br /><br /><br />
At the PFS stage it will be important to gain a thorough understanding of the legislative           <br /><br /><br />
framework as it applies to environmental and social aspects of major projects such as this.         <br /><br /><br />
﻿This will enable .‘itraiegies'plans lo be developed and implemented with respect to gaining        <br /><br /><br />
access and tenure to the required deposits and land and achieving government approval for          <br /><br /><br />
the project. In addition to meeting the environmental legislation requirements of the              <br /><br /><br />
Government of Liberia, it is considered best practice to also match the guidelines issued by       <br /><br /><br />
international agencies, in particular the World Bank’s (WB) Equator Principles and the             <br /><br /><br />
International Finance Corporation’s (1FC) Performance Standards, The 1FC requirements              <br /><br /><br />
must be complied with if finance is sought from an Equator Principles financial institution.       <br /><br /><br />
The PFS stage of a project is when information and data relating to the environmental              <br /><br /><br />
and social footprint of the project is collected. This information will be collected through       <br /><br /><br />
initial baseline studies, as well as through ongoing environmental monitoring of the project       <br /><br /><br />
activities, over the duration of the exploration phase of works. In order to fully assess the      <br /><br /><br />
environmental impacts of the project will be necessary to have data available that represents      <br /><br /><br />
the environmental baseline prior to commencement of development activities associated with         <br /><br /><br />
the project. It is anticipated that there is minimal environmental or biodiversity information     <br /><br /><br />
currently available at the required level of detail for the areas that fall within the project     <br /><br /><br />
footprint. will therefore be necessary to engage suitably qualified professionals to               <br /><br /><br />
undertake baseline studies. It will be important to commence these studies at an early stage in    <br /><br /><br />
the project lifecycle to allow sufficient time to collect data in both wet and dry seasons where   <br /><br /><br />
relevant. It will also be important to have the information available prior to the project design  <br /><br /><br />
being fixed because late design changes to mitigate environmental or social impacts can add        <br /><br /><br />
unnecessary cost and result in delays.                                                             <br /><br /><br />
The Environmental and Social Impact Assessment (ESIA) Scoping Study will define the                <br /><br /><br />
baseline data required but it is envisaged that the following surveys/studies will be required     <br /><br /><br />
i) a review of the project areas with respect to protected areas, ii) vegetation and fauna         <br /><br /><br />
surveys, of the areas impacted by the project, iii)’background air quality survey, iv) surface     <br /><br /><br />
and groundwater studies, v) climate and noise surveys and vi) a marine survey at for the port.     <br /><br /><br />
In order to fully assess the social impact of the project on human communities likely to be        <br /><br /><br />
affected by the project, it will be necessary to collect baseline data in the following areas i)   <br /><br /><br />
social footprint of the project, ii) social and administrative structures within the region, iii)  <br /><br /><br />
demographic study, iv) education and health statistics, v) land use and tenure, vi) livelihood     <br /><br /><br />
activities & employment opportunities, vii) cultural heritage, public attitudes and perceptions    <br /><br /><br />
and infrastructure and public services. At the PFS stage the social professionals on the project   <br /><br /><br />
team will also commence the compilation of a stakeholder register. The stakeholders will           <br /><br /><br />
include government agencies, non-government organisations (NGO's) and key members of               <br /><br /><br />
the local communities. In addition a consultation strategy and a stakeholder engagement plan       <br /><br /><br />
will be developed and implementation of the consultation plan will also commence at this           <br /><br /><br />
stage. The information collected as a result of the studies outlined above will be collated,       <br /><br /><br />
summarised and presented as a report, or Project Brief, prepared pursuant to section 8 of the      <br /><br /><br />
Environment Protection Law. The Project Brief will enable a preliminary assessment of              <br /><br /><br />
potential environmental and social impacts to be conducted. The project Brief will also be         <br /><br /><br />
used in later stages of the project such as the Environmental and Social Impact Assessment         <br /><br /><br />
process and in the preparation of environmental and social management plans. Preliminary           <br /><br /><br />
Environmental and Social Design Criteria (ESDC) will be prepared for the project. The              <br /><br /><br />
ESDC will be based on Liberian legislative requirements. World Bank guidelines, World              <br /><br /><br />
Health Organisation (WHO) guidelines, best practice guidelines and other appropriate               <br /><br /><br />
standards and limits together with company’s environmental and social objectives. Social           <br /><br /><br />
criteria will include the findings of the study of people’s perceptions and values. The criteria   <br /><br /><br />
will cover all aspects of the project. The ESDC is a document that will be used by the design      <br /><br /><br />
team lo ensure the project achieves the required level of performance with respect to              <br /><br /><br />
environmental and social impacts. In order to achieve development approval from the                <br /><br /><br />
﻿ Governmcnpa it will be necessary to conduct an environmental and social impact                      <br /><br /><br />
 assessment |ject. The Scoping Study for the ESI A will be developed during the PFS                  <br /><br /><br />
 and wj'IJ imtis of reference for the subsequent Environmental Impact Study. The                     <br /><br /><br />
 Scoping Stu^flect the potential environmental and social footprint of the project and               <br /><br /><br />
 be based Ojfcquirementx of the Government of Liberia (i.c. section 11 of the                        <br /><br /><br />
 Environmenlon Law) and/or the World Bank/IFC as appropriate. The Scoping Study                      <br /><br /><br />
 will be issueiemment agencies and other relevant stakeholders for comment prior to                  <br /><br /><br />
 commencemJhe baseline data collection studies to ensure that it aligns with their                   <br /><br /><br />
 expectations, j                                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
2.12 Capital Estimates                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
The capital c timates prepared for each project alternative for the mines, processing                <br /><br /><br />
plants, rail roa l allocated place at free port of Monrovia including LMC and NIOC piers             <br /><br /><br />
rehabilitation t • PFS level will typically have an accuracy range of ±25%, sufficient for           <br /><br /><br />
ranking, reject and selection of alternatives. The estimates will be prepared using a                <br /><br /><br />
mixture of de d costing; budget quotes, database costs, preliminary engineering, and                 <br /><br /><br />
factored costinj >ing industry accepted experience factors. A preliminary risk analysis will         <br /><br /><br />
be applied to c , and schedule using probabilistic analysis techniques. This will assist in          <br /><br /><br />
determining thequantifcation of the project contingencies (capital and schedule) and the             <br /><br /><br />
associated resenes o' risk amounts that arc congruent with the risk, appetite of the project.        <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
2.13    Operating C#st Estimates                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
The operating cost estimates prepared for each project alternative at the PFS level will             <br /><br /><br />
typically have an accuracy range of ±25%, sufficient for ranking, rejection and selection of         <br /><br /><br />
alternatives. The estimates for consumables, labour, spares, administration, etc. will be            <br /><br /><br />
prepared using a mixture of detailed costing; budget quotes, database costs, preliminary             <br /><br /><br />
engineering, and factored costing using industry accepted experience (actors.                        <br /><br /><br />
2.14    Ownership, Legal and Contractual                                                             <br /><br /><br />
This chapter of the PFS will address issues relating to ownership of the resource, royalties,        <br /><br /><br />
ownership of land and surface rights and the status of any negotiations pertaining thereto. It       <br /><br /><br />
will also address sovereign risk, the legal a^d regulatory systems applicable and taxation. At       <br /><br /><br />
the PFS stage the intended contractual strategies for sales and marketing, labour, major inputs      <br /><br /><br />
(electricity, water, etc.) and intellectual properly will be developed.                              <br /><br /><br />
2.15 Financial Evaluations                                                                           <br /><br /><br />
A complete financial evaluation of the selected alternative only will be presented in the PFS        <br /><br /><br />
report. It will be structured so as to address company's investment criteria and hurdles and         <br /><br /><br />
may be carried out by company or by the PFS contractor. The economic analysis for a major            <br /><br /><br />
project such as Western Cluster is intended to capture all of the key aspects of the preliminary     <br /><br /><br />
work that has been completed (engineering, market study, etc.) to develop potential outcomes         <br /><br /><br />
that can be used to evaluate potential opportunities and risks. During the PFS, a number of          <br /><br /><br />
options will be evaluated at a sufficient level of detail to select a preferred alternative for the  <br /><br /><br />
subsequent DFS. The economic analysis at this stage of development will be budgetary, to             <br /><br /><br />
help i) determine the validity of the business case, ii) select the best project option, iii) set    <br /><br /><br />
project objectives, including target cost and schedule, iv) decide on whether to proceed to a        <br /><br /><br />
DFS (“go or no-go decision point”), and v) define the scope and work plan for a DFS.                 <br /><br /><br />
Discounted cash flow (DCF) analysis is a valuation method used to estimate the                       <br /><br /><br />
attractiveness of an investment opportunity using future free cash flow projections and              <br /><br /><br />
discounting them (using the weighted average cost of capital) to arrive at a present value,          <br /><br /><br />
﻿which is used to evaluate the potential for investment. If the value arrived at through DCF          <br /><br /><br />
analysis is higher than the current cost of the investment, the opportunity may be a good one.       <br /><br /><br />
A DCF model will be developed for Western Cluster, including the following key inputs i)             <br /><br /><br />
revenues and production rate will be based on projected throughput and iron ore prices taken         <br /><br /><br />
from the preliminary market study, ii) capital and operating cost estimates, iii) a preliminary      <br /><br /><br />
estimate of working capital requirements, iv) a proposed capital structure and proposed              <br /><br /><br />
financing, discussed and agreed with Company’s shareholders to determine the appropriate             <br /><br /><br />
cost of capital (preliminary at this stage), v) an allowance for taxes based on local regulations,   <br /><br /><br />
vi) foreign exchange rate assumptions taken from consensus forecasts, and vii) a list of risk        <br /><br /><br />
items not included in the capital cost estimate will be prepared, and an allowance made for          <br /><br /><br />
risk management and mitigation (based on experience and benchmarking).                               <br /><br /><br />
The financial model wiil be used to evaluate, for each option being considered, i) project           <br /><br /><br />
internal rate of return (IRR), ii) net present value (NPV), iii) payback period, and iv)             <br /><br /><br />
sensitivity of NPV to variations to major input parameters, including product price, capital         <br /><br /><br />
cost, major operating cost inputs (diesel, labour, etc.), foreign exchange rate, and other           <br /><br /><br />
relevant variables. The results wiil be used to help determine the viability of the project, areas   <br /><br /><br />
of potential risk and opportunity and the best project option for the subsequent DFS.                <br /><br /><br />
2.16 Work Plan                                                                                       <br /><br /><br />
As part of the PFS a work plan for the further development of the project will be prepared           <br /><br /><br />
which will include i) activities for commencing the DFS, ii) DFS activities, iii) pre-project        <br /><br /><br />
commitments required, iv) a detailed DFS schedule, v) a preliminary project schedule, and vi)        <br /><br /><br />
a DFS cost estimate and implementation plan etc.                                                     <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                     <br /><br /><br />

                                                   4:! <br /><br /><br />
﻿                                    EXHIBIT 1A                                                      <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
                      FORM OF CLASS A MINING LICENSE                                                <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
This CLASS A MINING LICENSE (this “Mining License"! is dated [ J, 2[...J and made                   <br /><br /><br />
by and between the MINISTER OF LANDS, MINES & ENERGY OF THE REPUBLIC                                <br /><br /><br />
OF LIBERIA (hereinafter referred to as the “MINISTER”), and WESTERN CLUSTER                         <br /><br /><br />
LIMITED, a corporation organized under the laws of Liberia (hereinafter referred to as the          <br /><br /><br />
“CONCESSIONAIRE”).                                                                                  <br /><br /><br />
Capitalized terms used but not defined herein shall have the meaning ascribed to them in the        <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
Mineral Development Agreement, dated _____, 2011 among the Government of the                        <br /><br /><br />
Republic of Liberia, Western Cluster Limited and Elenilto Minerals & Mining Limited (the            <br /><br /><br />
“MPA”) or, if not defined therein, in the Minerals and Mining Law 2000 Part I, Title 23 of          <br /><br /><br />
the Liberian Code of Laws Revised (the “Minerals and Mining Law”), any regulations issued           <br /><br /><br />
under the Minerals and Mining Law (except to the extent provided in the MDA) or the                 <br /><br /><br />
Exploration Regulations.                                                                            <br /><br /><br />
WITNESSETH:                                                                                         <br /><br /><br />
WHEREAS, the Government and the CONCESSIONAIRE have concluded, and the                              <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
CONCESSIONAIRE is materially in compliance with, the provisions of the MDA relating to              <br /><br /><br />
the application for a Mining License;                                                               <br /><br /><br />
WHEREAS, the CONCESSIONAIRE is an Eligible Applicant for a Mining License;                          <br /><br /><br />
WHEREAS, the MINISTER has the power to grant the CONCESSIONAIRE a Mining                            <br /><br /><br />
License as contemplated in the MDA, and to permit the CONCESSIONAIRE to conduct the                 <br /><br /><br />
Operations as contemplated by the MDA;                                                              <br /><br /><br />
NOW, THEREFORE, for and in consideration of the premises, the mutual promises made                  <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
by and between the Government and the CONCESSIONAIRE (hereinafter referred to as “the               <br /><br /><br />
Parties”), and the terms and conditions herein contained and in the MDA, it is hereby               <br /><br /><br />
irrevocably provided as follows:                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
Grant of Mining License                                                                             <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
1.    The MINISTER hereby grants to the CONCESSIONAIRE a Mining License for the                     <br /><br /><br />
Proposed Production Area, together with all related rights and privileges to allow the              <br /><br /><br />
CONCESSIONAIRE to conduct the Operations contemplated by the MDA. This                              <br /><br /><br />
grant is subject to the provisions of the MDA. To the extent that there is any conflict             <br /><br /><br />
between the terms of this Mining License or any Regulations and the terms of the                    <br /><br /><br />
MDA, the MDA shall prevail.                                                                         <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
Term of License                                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
2.    The initial term of the Mining License shall commence on the date first above written         <br /><br /><br />
and shall be for twenty-five (25) years unless earlier terminated pursuant to any                   <br /><br /><br />
Section of the VIDA. The CONCESSIONAIRE shall have the right to renew the                           <br /><br /><br />
Mining License, for consecutive additional terms not to exceed twenty-five (25) years               <br /><br /><br />
each subject to the provisions of the MDA.                                                          <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                  A <br /><br /><br />
﻿Discovery of Other Minerals                                                                       <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                  <br /><br /><br />
3.    Subject to any prior rights of third parties arising as a result of exploration activities  <br /><br /><br />
of such third parties permitted under Section 4.5 of the MDA, if the Company                      <br /><br /><br />
discovers other Minerals within a Production Area the Company may apply for an                    <br /><br /><br />
amendment to this Mining License or for a new Mining License to cover the new                     <br /><br /><br />
Minerals in accordance with this Mining License and the Agreement and the                         <br /><br /><br />
Government shall not unreasonably withhold its approval of such amendment or grant                <br /><br /><br />
of a new Mining License provided that the Company has submitted to the                            <br /><br /><br />
Government an amendment to the existing Feasibility Report or, at the Government’s                <br /><br /><br />
discretion, a new Feasibility Report, for such other Minerals.                                    <br /><br /><br />
Additional Exploration within the Proposed Production Area                                        <br /><br /><br />
4.    If the CONCESSIONAIRE wishes to carry out additional Exploration within the                 <br /><br /><br />
Proposed Production Area it may do so in accordance with the MDA.                                 <br /><br /><br />
Surface Rights                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
5.    Without prejudice to the generality of the rights provided in the MDA, the grant of the     <br /><br /><br />
Mining License shall, pursuant to the provisions of Section 6.7(d) of the Minerals and            <br /><br /><br />
Mining Law, carry the following surface rights:                                                   <br /><br /><br />
(i)    Erection of habitations, office buildings, mill buildings, engine houses, storehouses;     <br /><br /><br />
(ii)    Building of dumps, ditches for drainage', roads within the surface boundaries of the      <br /><br /><br />
Proposed Production Area;                                                                         <br /><br /><br />
(iii)    Making trenches and open cuts, constructed for and necessary Mining Operation;           <br /><br /><br />
(iv)    Cutting of timber only insofar as it is necessary to clear for buildings and such works   <br /><br /><br />
as are mentioned in (i) to (iii) above and to use in construction of the mining site; and         <br /><br /><br />
(v)    Use of water and other resources necessary for the execution of the work.                  <br /><br /><br />
Rights to Dispose of Minerals                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
6.    The CONCESSIONAIRE shall have the right to freely dispose of within Liberia all             <br /><br /><br />
Minerals extracted under the terms of this Mining License, and may export all such                <br /><br /><br />
Minerals in their original or changed form subject to the specific provisions of the              <br /><br /><br />
MDA.                                                                                              <br /><br /><br />
Reports by the CONCESSIONAIRE                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
7.    The CONCESSIONAIRE shall submit to the MINIS TER reports in accordance with                 <br /><br /><br />
the MDA.                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
Inspection of Mining Premises and Books                                                           <br /><br /><br />
8.    The MINISTER shall have the right in accordance with the terms of the MDA to                <br /><br /><br />
order an inspection at any time of the Proposed Production Area and of the books and              <br /><br /><br />
records ofthe CONCESSIONAIRE.                                                                     <br /><br /><br />
﻿ SECTION 704. ROYALTIES AND SURFACE RENT                                                                                <br /><br /><br />
(a)    Royalties. A royalty is due and payable to the Government of Liberia at the time of each shipment and in the     <br /><br /><br />
amount of the stated percent of the value of commercially shipped mineral, regardless of whether the shipment           <br /><br /><br />
is a sale or other disposition:                                                                                         <br /><br /><br />
(1)    Iron ore. 4.5 percent.                                                                                           <br /><br /><br />
(2)    Gold and other base metals- 3 percent.                                                                           <br /><br /><br />
(3)    Commercial diamonds. 5 percent.                                                                                  <br /><br /><br />
(b)    Surface Rent. A producer who has a mineral exploration license or a Class A mining license shall pay an annual   <br /><br /><br />
surface rent.                                                                                                           <br /><br /><br />
(1)    The surface rent is:                                                                                             <br /><br /><br />
(A)    Land within a mineral exploration license area. US S0.20 (Twenty Untied States Cents) per acre.                  <br /><br /><br />
(B)    Land within a mining license area.                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
(i)    Year 1-10 US S5.00 peracre.                                                                                      <br /><br /><br />
(ii)    Year 11-25 US $10.00 per acre.                                                                                  <br /><br /><br />
(2)    Annual payments are due on or before the effective date of the agreement and on the agreement anniversary        <br /><br /><br />
date thereafter-                                                                                                        <br /><br /><br />
(3)    Surface cent amounts stated in this section shall be subject to inflationary adjustment in accordance with the   <br /><br /><br />
GDP Implicit Price Deflator as published and revised from time to time to time by the U.S. Department of                <br /><br /><br />
Commerce, Bureau of Economic Analysis ("the deflator"). The inflation-adjusted rent shall be effective                  <br /><br /><br />
January I of each calendar year based on the ratio of the value of the revised deflator for the second quarter          <br /><br /><br />
of the immediately preceding calendar year to the value of the revised deflator for the second quarter of               <br /><br /><br />
2008.                                                                                                                   <br /><br /><br />
SECTION 705. DETERMINATION 01< TAXABLE INCOME OFMININC PROJECTS                                                         <br /><br /><br />
(a)    Gross Income. The gross income of a mining project includes---                                                   <br /><br /><br />
(1)    All revenues resulting from production and other operations carried out under the project's mining license;      <br /><br /><br />
(2)    Any other income that the project receives from business activity or investment accruing in, derived from,       <br /><br /><br />
brought into or received in Liberia, including currency gains when realized (but not gains from hedging                 <br /><br /><br />
transactions), less the deductions set forth in subsection (b).                                                         <br /><br /><br />
(b)    Deductions Allowed from Gross Income. In accordance with the rules of Chapter 2, ali expenditures incurred       <br /><br /><br />
during the tax period wholly, exclusively, and necessarily in connection with project operations (including non¬        <br /><br /><br />
capital operating costs but excluding capital costs except to the extent of the annual allowance for depreciation),     <br /><br /><br />
are allowed as deductions, including but not limited to the following items:                                            <br /><br /><br />
(1)    Royalties and surface rent (as specified in Section 704), and fees and rent paid for the privilege of a mining   <br /><br /><br />
exploration iicense or a Class A mining license in accordance with the Mining Law.                                      <br /><br /><br />
(2)    An allowance for depreciation of mining plant and equipment in accordance with the depreciation rules oT         <br /><br /><br />
Chapter 2, subject to the special rule of Section 706.                                                                  <br /><br /><br />
(3)    A carryforward of net operating loss from a prior year to the extent permiited under Section 203(e) as           <br /><br /><br />
modified by Section 707.                                                                                                <br /><br /><br />
I-                                                                                                                      <br /><br /><br />
﻿(c) Form of Organization Disregarded. Regardless of the legal form of organization adopted by one or more                 <br /><br /><br />
persons having an interest in a mining project, a producer's taxable income shall be determined separately for            <br /><br /><br />
each mining production project, and a person with an interest in more than one mining production project shall            <br /><br /><br />
not be permitted to consolidate income or loss of one mining production project with that of any other.                   <br /><br /><br />
(1)    For purposes of determining income tax, income from a mining project is considered to be income of a               <br /><br /><br />
resident legal person or of a Section 803 permanent establishment taxable according to the rules applicable               <br /><br /><br />
to a resident legal person. Taxable income and income tax liability are determined under provisions of the                <br /><br /><br />
regular income tax of Chapter 2 subject to special rules provided in this Chapter.                                        <br /><br /><br />
(2)    In accordance with Section 10(z), a producer who holds a Class A mining license ("license") granted under          <br /><br /><br />
the Mining Law is considered to have an interest in the mining project that is the subject of the license and             <br /><br /><br />
is the taxpayer legally responsible for paying tax with respect to income of the project.                                 <br /><br /><br />
(3)    The Chapter 9 filing and advance payment rules for the regular income tax apply to a producer with income          <br /><br /><br />
from a mining project.                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
(^) Mining Law. The Mining Law governs non-tax terms of extraction of minerals in Liberia, including licenses             <br /><br /><br />
and fees.                                                                                                                 <br /><br /><br />
(e) Valuation of Minerals. Extracted minerals shall be valued for all purposes of this Code using the valuation           <br /><br /><br />
method described in Section 703.                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
(0 US Dollar Accounting. Books and records of a mining project may be kept in 1,Iberian or US Dollars, but a              <br /><br /><br />
mining project's tax and taxable income shall be determined in US Dollars.                                                <br /><br /><br />
(g)    Consolidated Account. An amount that a producer is required to contribute to a development fund or other fund      <br /><br /><br />
specified in this Chapter, or a payment a producer is required to make under the Mining Law, is to be paid into           <br /><br /><br />
the consolidated account.                                                                                                 <br /><br /><br />
(h)    Compliance. An amount clue or amount in default under an agreement between a mining project producer and           <br /><br /><br />
the Government of Liberia is treated as a tax liability under this Code, and is subject to the same procedural            <br /><br /><br />
requirements (including penalties, fees, and interest).                                                                   <br /><br /><br />
SECTION 702. RATE OF TAX                                                                                                  <br /><br /><br />
(a)    Rate. The rate of tax on taxable income from a mining project shall be 30 percent.                                 <br /><br /><br />
(b)    Surtax on Income from High-Yield Projects. Income from a high-yield mining project, as defined in Section          <br /><br /><br />
730, shall be subject to a higher marginal rate of income tax on taxable income under the conditions and using            <br /><br /><br />
the calculation method set out in that section.                                                                           <br /><br /><br />
SECTION 703. VALUATION                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
(a)    Genera! Rule. Minerals extracted by a mining project are valued for all purposes at fair market value f.o.b.       <br /><br /><br />
Liberia without reduction for claims, counterclaims, discounts, commissions, or any other asserted offset or              <br /><br /><br />
deduction.                                                                                                                <br /><br /><br />
(b)    Cross-Reference. The fair market value f.o.b. Liberia is determined for the day of shipment in accordance with     <br /><br /><br />
Section I0(cc), and in the case of a product for which there is a reliable international price index, as specified in     <br /><br /><br />
regulations referencing that index.                                                                                       <br /><br /><br />
(c)    Gold. The fair market value of gold f.o.b. Liberia is the London afternoon gold price fixing ("London PM fix")     <br /><br /><br />
for the day the gold is shipped from Liberia.                                                                             <br /><br /><br />
(d)    Advance Pricing Agreement. The Government of Liberia and a producer may agree to a transfer pricing                <br /><br /><br />
methodology in an advance pricing agreement in accordance with Section 18.                                                <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                       .1 <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
﻿ (4)    Mining Project The term "mining project" means mineral exploration, mineral development, or mining                     <br /><br /><br />
 carried out by a mining project producer within a mineral exploration license area or a mining license area.                  <br /><br /><br />
 (5)    Mining Production Project. The term “mining production project” means mineral development, mining, or                  <br /><br /><br />
 related activities carried out by a mining project producer within a mining license area.                                     <br /><br /><br />
 (5) Other Mining Activity. Mineral exploration, mining development, mining, or related activities earned out                  <br /><br /><br />
 under any category of license issued in accordance with the Mining Law other than a mining exploration                        <br /><br /><br />
 license or a Class A mining license is not a "mining project" and is taxable under the general rules of                       <br /><br /><br />
 Chapter 2 rather than as a "mining project" under this Chapter, except that the royalty rates of Section 704                  <br /><br /><br />
 apply to the sale or other disposition of minerals mined under a license other than a Class A license.                        <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
(d)    Capital Goods. For purposes of this Chapter, the term "capital goods" has the same meaning as in Section                <br /><br /><br />
1001(g)(5).                                                                                                                    <br /><br /><br />
(e)    Commercial Production.                                                                                                  <br /><br /><br />
(1)    A mining or petroleum project begins "commercial production” on the dale of the fust shipment of mineral                <br /><br /><br />
or petroleum extracted from a mining license area or petroleum area as paptof a regular program of profit-                     <br /><br /><br />
seeking activity.                                                                                                              <br /><br /><br />
(2)    Commercial production ends on the last day of a tax period in which the number of shipments is less than                <br /><br /><br />
one-tenth of the average shipments during the first three years of commercial production.                                      <br /><br /><br />
(f)    Exploration Expenditures.                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
(1) Mining. “Mineral exploration expenditures” are costs associated with exploration of a mineral exploration                  <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
license area to determine whether it is possible to develop the area for production of minerals.                               <br /><br /><br />
(g)    Development Expenditures.                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
(1) Mining. “Mining development expenditures” are costs associated with the development of a mining license                    <br /><br /><br />
area, or a part thereof, to prepare it for commercial production.                                                              <br /><br /><br />
(h)    Attribution of Expenditures. Exploration, development, and capital goods expenditures incurred prior to a               <br /><br /><br />
project's first tax period are attributable to it for income tax purposes as follows---                                        <br /><br /><br />
(i) Mining Project. In Che case of a mining project, expenditures incurred prior to the existence of any mining                <br /><br /><br />
production project within a mineral exploration license yea are attributable io the first mining production                    <br /><br /><br />
project established within the first mining license area within a mineral exploration license area.                            <br /><br /><br />
Subsequent expenditures in the mineral exploration license area after the date of the first Class A mining                     <br /><br /><br />
license, but outside the first mining license area, are attributed to subsequent mining production projects                    <br /><br /><br />
under subsequent Class A mining licenses issued for the mineral exploration license area. Exploration,                         <br /><br /><br />
development, and capital goods expenditures not attributable to a mining production project described in                       <br /><br /><br />
this paragraph are not deductible in determining taxable income.                                                               <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
SUBCHAPTER A. MINING                                                                                                           <br /><br /><br />
SECTION 701. SCOPE OF SUBCHAPTER                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
(a)    Income Taxation. In accordance with the provisions of Part II (ty the extent applicable) and as specifically            <br /><br /><br />
provided in this Chapter, income tax is imposed on taxable income from a mining project (as defined in Section                 <br /><br /><br />
700). In case of inconsistency with other provisions of Part II, the provisions of this subchapter are                         <br /><br /><br />
determinative.                                                                                                                 <br /><br /><br />
(b)    Rate of Tax. Taxable income from a mining project is subject to income tax at the rate stated in Section 702.           <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
                                          O.                                                                                   <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                             I <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                         Y*    <br /><br /><br />
﻿ must disclose the error or omission in its next-filed tax return or other scheduled report (or sootier as                <br /><br /><br />
 specified in regulations).                                                                                               <br /><br /><br />
 (b)    Guidelines. The term "Guidelines" means the guidelines established by the Organization for Economic               <br /><br /><br />
 Cooperation and Development and by the United Nations with respect to transfer pricing.                                  <br /><br /><br />
 (c)    Obligations of the Parties In negotiation of a TPM, the Ministry of Finance and the producer are required to      <br /><br /><br />
 take the Guidelines into account.                                                                                        <br /><br /><br />
                                                                                                                          <br /><br /><br />
